content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on winnings from state lotteries or gambling establishments to ensure payment of child support. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act includes procedures for withholding child support arrearages from insurance payments or settlements. The amended policy suspends insurance payments until a response is received from the State agency regarding child support arrearages. If arrearages exist, the policy withholds and pays the lesser of the payment amount or arrearage amount. The policy suspends insurance payments until a response is received from the State agency regarding child support arrearages, and if arrearages exist, the payment is withheld and paid to the State agency for distribution. The policy suspends insurance payments until a response is received from the State agency regarding child support arrearages. If arrearages exist, the payment is withheld and paid to the State agency for distribution. If the State seizes property forfeited by an individual due to a criminal conviction, the State must hold the property until an inquiry is made and a response received from the State. The policy suspends insurance payments until a response is received from the State agency regarding child support arrearages. If arrearages exist, the payment is withheld and paid to the State agency for distribution. If there is an arrearage, the property is sold to satisfy claims and costs deducted from the proceeds. The policy suspends insurance payments until a response is received from the State agency regarding child support arrearages. If arrearages exist, the payment is withheld and paid to the State agency for distribution. Payment in respect to a decedent should be suspended until an inquiry is made to the State agency. The policy suspends insurance payments until a response is received from the State agency regarding child support arrearages. If arrearages exist, the payment is withheld and paid to the State agency for distribution. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures where State licensing departments cannot issue or renew licenses for noncustodial parents with outstanding warrants related to child support proceedings. State licensing departments cannot issue or renew licenses for individuals delinquent in child support payments without consent from a State prosecutor or court order. A 60-day temporary license may be granted during an expedited inquiry and review process. State motor vehicle departments are prohibited from issuing or renewing driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with outstanding warrants related to child support proceedings. Temporary licenses may be granted for a 60-day period. State motor vehicle departments cannot issue or renew driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with child support warrant. Temporary licenses may be granted for a 60-day period. If a warrant is issued, the individual must demonstrate why their license or registration should not be suspended until the warrant is removed. Temporary licenses or registrations may be granted in such cases. State motor vehicle departments may suspend driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with child support warrants. Temporary licenses may be granted for a 60-day period, pending compliance with the order or removal of the warrant. SEC. 4. ATTACHMENT OF BANK ACCOUNTS. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)) is amended to allow seizure of funds in a bank account to pay child support arrears. The amendment allows seizure of funds from a bank account to pay child support arrears through an administrative process established under State law, with an expedited opportunity for the account holder to challenge the seizure. If the account holder fails to successfully challenge the seizure, the institution may be required to pay the arrearage amount or the amount on deposit in the account to the entity with the right to collect the arrearage. SEC. 5. REPORTING OF CHILD SUPPORT OBLIGATIONS TO CREDIT BUREAUS. Section 466(a)(7) of the Social Security Act is amended to require courts and administrative agencies to report child support orders to consumer reporting agencies. The amendment to Section 466(a)(7) of the Social Security Act now requires courts and administrative agencies to report child support orders to consumer reporting agencies, including the obligation to pay child support and the amount of the obligation. SEC. 6. Liability of grandparents for financial support of their grandchildren. Amends Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act to make each parent liable for the financial support of their child if the individual is unable to provide such support.
